title: Has anybody been stressed to a point that suddenly you felt that nothing else matters and you became numbed? - Quora

response.answer_text: Over the course of attending college, I became convinced of the probability of nuclear annihilation. In the face of society’s total collapse, everything else in my life seemed mundane; my education, career, relationships, pastimes, held no meaning as I was certain they would be lost, but I followed them blindly, knowing that having some semblance of life is important. I mourned them as such, despite still having all of those aspects present in my life. I learned to feel comfortable on my own, independent, and I took great lengths to tune my education for survival afterwards. I read about engineering, psychology, weapons usage, growing crops and raising livestock, cooking and preserving food, computers and technology, electricity, vehicles, navigation, forestry, weather, and a whole host of other topics. I posited that at least one person I know could survive as well, so I maintained a few close friendships, in the hope that once the dust settled, I wouldn’t have to start over alone. The people in my life became beacons; I appreciated the good ones even more because I knew they would be gone eventually. I put no serious thought into my career, because I didn’t think I could have one, so I aimed for whichever job sounded the most engaging in the meantime. I spent a lot of time doing things simply because they would be impossible after bombs started dropping; I went out with my friends, played games over the internet, went to museums and art exhibitions, traveled to other countries, visited my grandparents pet my friends’ cats, loved ferociously, sang in a choir, and took every chance I had to notice nature at work. It was all a sham, going through the motions to make sure I didn’t miss anything before it was too late. But every day, I woke up, and still no nukes had been dropped.Every day I had one more reason to believe my life would continue to continue.Every day, I saw a little bit more good in the worldAnd eventually, I realized that maybe, just maybe, nuclear annihilation wasn’t imminent. That it could be prevented. I couldn’t stand the idea. I had wasted all that time preparing for something terrible that might not even happen. But in the meantime, I had gained so many useful skills for leading a happy life.And now I know that I’m more than capable of spending the rest of my life happy with myself, because I’ve done it before, so I can do it again, and again, and again. I’m no longer certain that nuclear warfare is imminent, but never again will I settle for less than what I need, because I just never know when everything could come to a screeching halt

Yes. This is classic “burnout”. I’ve experienced it several times, most recently when I attended grad school while working full time. if you're experiencing burnout, you need to care for yourself. For just a moment, pretend like you're someone else, evaluating your habits. Are you sleeping 8 hours? Are you exercising? Are you drinking too much or self medicating in some other way? You need two things: rest, and recreation. Not work-like hobbies. Recreation. Read a book. Play a sport. Go to a concert. Then set aside some time to just do nothing. Watch tv (and put the phone aside). Take a nap on a weekend. Go lay in the grass in a park. You have to practice these things to make them most effective, and it will be frustrating to try and relax, when it isn't working. Keep trying though. Try different things, and figure out what works for you in particular.

Oh hell ya I spent almost ten years working to improve my health which I did more than I could have ever thought possible only to Lose a close aunt and mentor, divorce finalized and social security determining my degenerative conditions improved and they were no longer going to pay me which in turn sent me into bankruptcy lost my house and car and a opportunity to be self supportive all with in 8 months. My Aunts death, my divorce and losing a substantial part of income were within a week numb doesn’t even begin to cover it.

Yes and stress in this context is actually a socially more acceptable word for depression. Numbness is one of the effects of depression. I hope you have access to resources to learn from and eventually overcome depression.
